name: hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/7981/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg hard coal (useable output) in the specific region with an energy content of 20.1 MJ/kg pit coal. Life time is assumed to be 20 years for operation. Additionally, 100 years of life time are taken into account due to the assumption that land after operation is destroyed and not useable for a long time. Thus, land recultivation is not considered in the dataset. After 120 years, revegetation of land is expected. This dataset is based on various literature studies on material flows and energy use. Data regarding land use for operational areas for infrastructure, extraction areas and dump areas have been estimated. Land use for affected water supply areas only represent rough estimations. Data regarding land use are not valid for specific regions, for this, higher uncertainties are considered. In this dataset infrastructure requirements are applied to total production over the life time. For this, the total production has to be estimated. A total production over life time of 3*10^10 kg is assumed. This figure represents an average value and is not representative for single mines or specific conditions. ;The dataset represents the production of 1 Kg hard coal in Australia. Australia has the fourth largest share of coal reserves in the world. Most of the coal  is exported. 77 % of  the nations coal production was shipped overseas in 2013-14.In Australia, nearly 80 per cent of coal is produced from open-cut mines. The dataset represents data from both opencast as well as underground mines.In Australia black coal occurs in all states, but Queensland (63 per cent) and New South Wales (23 per cent) have the largest share.

Mining process starting from hard coal, in ground.

This activity ends with 1 kg hard coal at the coal mine. This dataset includes land use during operation, emissions into water and air, water extraction during pumping, energy requirements for operation, explosives, as well as the deposition of spoil. This dataset doesn’t include noise emissions; however they are expected to be wide-ranging. The amount of geothermal energy directly or indirectly emitted to air by extraction of hot pit water or increased evaporation is not considered due to the lack of data.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The data has been collected from 2015 -16 onwards and are estimated to be valid till 2020
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Region specific.;In Australia black coal occurs in all states, but Queensland (63 per cent) and New South Wales (23 per cent) have the largest share.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Opencast mining: Compared to lignite, hard coal seams are much thinner but in most cases up to 20 seams are located one above the other. In general seam thickness ranges from 2 to 10 meters; the seams are located up to a depth of 100 meters. In hard coal opencast mines often lorries and bucket excavators are used. Due to the fact that hard coal is embedded in hard rock formations and hard coal itself is rather hard, the rock formations have to be blasted, thus significant amounts of explosives are required.;Underground mining: In underground mines seam thickness ranges from 0.7 to 5 meters. It is also possible to extract seams which are located one upon the other. Seams with a thickness below 0.7 meters can not be mined cost effectively. Depths range from below 100 meters u to 1000 meters. ;;In this dataset it is assumed that the total amount of coal is treated, particularly for export coal high calorific values and low sulfuric contents are required. Data regarding mine waste is based on Hinrichs. ;;In this dataset a processing efficiency factor of 95 % (opencast mining) and 92 % (underground mining) is assumed. Mine waste is partly recycled or disposed. Energetic use of flotation tailings in fluidized bed combustion is not included in the dataset due to insufficient information and insignificant amounts; assuming complete utilization, only 20 % of combustible matter can be recycled.;;;References:;Hinrichs W., Atmaca T., Neumann W., Thormann A. (1999) Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Rohstoffe. Teistudie Steinkohle. Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe, Staatliche geologische Dienste in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland. Hannover, Deutschland.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Part of the the data points have been kept from the dataset "hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, AU 1990-2002", accessed 28th November 2017. The dataset reffered to 2004, Röder, A., Ch. Bauer, R. Dones, Kohle, Dones R., Sachbilanzen von Energiesystemen. Final report No. 6 ecoinvent 2000, 6, Dübendorf and Villigen, CH, Swiss Centre for LCI, PSI, 4 - MeasurementOnSite, CD-ROM.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: The data is taken from various litreature sources available online. The data for overburden is taken from Queensland Goverment Data website.The other data for Land Ocuupation , Land transformation , diesel consumption, electricity andblasting has been taken from Carmichael Coal Mine project. Link for Queensland goverment data : https://data.qld.gov.au/dataset/coal-industry-review-statistical-tables/resource/95a7ed42-c011-4789-81ba-33c1d0a762d7   Link for Carmichael coal mine project: https://www.statedevelopment.qld.gov.au/assessments-and-approvals/carmichael-coal-environmental-impact-statement.html

exchanges.description:
Estimation. In opencast mines coal output amounts to 90-95 %; in underground mines depending on technology and geological conditions coal output ranges from 40 to 80 %. Due to the fact that only extracted coal is considered as resource, no mean value has to be estimated. The heat value of pit hard coal ranges from 15 to 30 MJ/kg. 

In this dataset 68 % of coal is mined in opencast mines. 

At coal mining, fossil resources are taken from the lithosphere. The energy content of these resources is used to calculate the CED (Cumulative Energy Demand). Energy content of hard coal varies for the different mining regions. Based on information about the mass of pit coal per t coal equivalent (1 t coal equivalent equals 29.308 GJ) the energy content of pit coal can be calculated. The calculated values are in accordance with data given in Hinrichs. In this mining region a gross calorific value of 20.1 MJ/kg pit coal can be estimated. Based on the results for the different mining regions and weighted with the annual total production an average value of 19.1 MJ/kg can be calculated. This figure represents the gross calorific value for the exchange "coal, hard, unspecified in ground". 

To calculate the CED a correction factor has to be used in order to consider differences between calorific values for different hard coals. This factor (i.e. relative resource extraction) corresponds to the gross calorific value of respective mining region divided by the average gross calorific value worldwide. 

In this region 1,228 kg pit coal/ kg useable output are extracted. 


Further references:

Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Hischier R., Hellweg S., Humbert S., Margni M., Nemecek T. and Spielmann M. (2004c) Implementation of Life Cycle Impact Assessment Methods. Final report ecoinvent 2000 No. 3. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, retrieved from: www.ecoinvent.ch <http://www.ecoinvent.ch>.
EcoSpold01Location=AU

Literature Value: The data for spoil has been taken from Queensland Goverment website. The total coal production from open cut mines is given as 208165815000 tons and total overburden is 19261211530000 bank cubic meters . The density for overburden usually lies between 1.6 to 1.8 tons per cubic meter , taking average fo the two above values density is considered as 1.65 tons per bcm. The data can be downloaded from the following links. https://data.qld.gov.au/dataset/coal-industry-review-statistical-tables/resource/95a7ed42-c011-4789-81ba-33c1d0a762d7

exchanges.description:
This data point has been kept from the dataset "hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, AU 1990-2002", accessed 28th November 2017. The data point has been reviewed and deemed as still appropriate.                                                                            Estimation. Regarding particulates, only those are considered which are not emitted during the combustion process and which are not deposited within the mining area. In AP 42 information about situational particle emission calculations and characteristical particle size distribution are given. 90 % of dust particles show sizes between 15 and 30 um, 10 % of dust particles are smaller than 15 um, 6 % of dust particles are smaller than 10 um and between 0.2 % und 1 % are smaller than 2.54 um. Regarding underground mining marginal emissions due to ventilation and slightly more emissions due to coal handling and the actual treatment step are estimated. Regarding opencast mining sharply increased emissions due to huge mining machines, lorries and open pits are estimated. Furthermore, emissions depend on climatic conditions (wind, precipitation, temperature) and the characteristics of coal (water content). In the literature figures regarding particle emissions range from 22 to 75 g/t. In this dataset particle emissions of 36 g/t are considered.

In various literature sources no information about other emissions emitted during underground mining are given respectively insignificant amounts are assumed, even though backfill processes show high specific emissions. 

In this dataset the following particle emissions factors are estimated: 

Particle emissions underground mining incl. treatment: 0.1 kg/t useable output

Particle emissions opencast mining incl. treatment: 0.4 kg/t useable output.

All emissions are assumed to be fly ash coarse particles (i.e. > 10 um).

Further references:

U.S. Departement of Energy (DOE) (1983) Energy Technonolgy Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. Washington, D.C.

ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.

Rentz O. (1991) Coal Use and Air Pollution Issues. In: Proceedings Coal in the Environment. London.

Regarding underground mines it is assumed that apart from electricity and diesel consumption also other energy carriers are required. For simplification reasons the consumption of other energy carriers is considered in this module. 

Energy consumption of other energy carriers (apart from diesel and electricity) is not estimated in Hinrichs. However, energy consumption of 110 MJ/ t usable output regarding underground mines is included in the dataset. 

Further references:

Hinrichs W., Atmaca T., Neumann W., Thormann A. (1999) Stoffmengenflüsse und Energiebedarf bei der Gewinnung ausgewählter mineralischer Rohstoffe. Teistudie Steinkohle. This data point has been kept from the dataset "hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, AU 1990-2002", accessed 28th November 2017. The data point has been reviewed and deemed as still appropriate.                                                                                Estimation. Regarding radon emissions extensive measurements were taken to develop a measurement methodology and to review operating conditions. (Müller et al. 1992) 

Radon concentrations in air flow when leaving the shaft installations are most important to estimate specific radon emissions. Immission measurements at different measuring points (also badly aerated sites) show figures between 80 and 500 Bq/m3 (i.e. mean value of 200 Bq/m3). It was not possible to allocate specific air flow amounts per t extracted coal. According to about 20 % of the radon concentration of coal plus twice the concentration are emitted via overburden, which corresponds to 12 Bq/kg coal. (UNSCEAR 1988) No differentiation between opencast and underground mines has been made due to the lack of data. This figure is used in this dataset. 

Further references:

Müller W.-U., Streffer C., Schabronath J. (1992) Die Radonexposition im Steinkohlenbergbau des Ruhrgebietes. In: Reiners Ch., Streffer C., Messerschmidt O., Strahlenrisiko durch Radon. 32. Jahrestagung der Vereinigung Deutscher Strahlenschutzärzte e.V. in Essen 30. Mai - 1. Juni 1991, Stuttgart.

exchanges.description: Calculated as the sum of fugitive CH4 emissions from mining, processing, storage and transporation of coal reported in the categories “1.B. 1. a. Coal mining and handling” and “1.B. 1. b. Solid fuel transformation” of the National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Reports of Annex I Countries (NIRs) in 2016 divided over the 2016 hard coal production volume of Australia. Australia reports a total of 1006kt fugitive CH4 emissions from coal mining and handling activities in 2016. Retrieved from the respective common reporting format (CRF) files released in 2018. Reference(s): The respective National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Reports and common reporting format (CRF), released in 2017, of Annex I countries can be downloaded at http://unfccc.int/national_reports/annex_i_ghg_inventories/national_inventories_submissions/items/10116.php, last accessed July 2018

This data point has been kept from the dataset "hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, AU 1990-2002", accessed 28th November 2017. The data point has been reviewed and deemed as still appropriate.                                                                          Estimation. Emission factors for washing processes are based on various literature sources. Estimations are valid both for opencast mining and for underground mining (no differentiation was possible due to the lack of data). Water amount of 200 l/t was estimated. (DOE 1983, Franke et al. 1989, Chadwick et al. 1987)

Further references:

U.S. Departement of Energy (DOE) (1980) Environmental Data - Energy Technonolgy Characterizations Coal. Washington, D.C.

U.S. Departement of Energy (DOE) (1983) Energy Technonolgy Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. Washington, D.C.

Brune D., Stehfest H. (1984) Folgen eines verstärkten Kohleeinsatzes in der Bundesrepublik Deutschland; Teilbericht: Umweltfolgeanalysen für Abwasseremissionen und feste Rückstände aus der Kohlegewinnung und -nutzung. Kernforschungszentrum Karlsruhe KfK 3526.

UNEP, "The environmental impacts of production and use of energy", Energy Report Series ERS-14-85, Nairobi 1985

ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.

Euler H. (1984) Umweltverträglichkeit von Energieversorgungskonzepten. Forschungen zur Raumentwicklung, Bonn.

Franke F.H., Guntermann K.J., Paersch M.J. (1989) Kohle und Umwelt. Bergbau Rohstoffe Energie, Band 26, Essen. 

Chadwick M.J., Highton N.H., Lindmann N (Ed.) (1987) Environmental Impacts of Coal Mining and Utilization. Oxford, UK.

Literature data : The above data is taken from Environment impact statement of  Carmichael Coal Mine project.50 % of the total land is assumed to be used for extraction and other 50% to be used as dump site. The environemental statement canbe downloaded from the below link https://www.statedevelopment.qld.gov.au/assessments-and-approvals/carmichael-coal-environmental-impact-statement.html The total mine area given is 44700 hectares with an annual prodction capacity of 60 MTPA with a mine life of 90 years.

This data point has been kept from the dataset "hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, AU 1990-2002", accessed 28th November 2017. The data point has been reviewed and deemed as still appropriate.                                                                          Estimation. At coal mining, fossil resources are taken from the lithosphere. The energy content of these resources is used to calculate the CED (Cumulative Energy Demand). Energy content of hard coal varies for the different mining regions. Based on information about the mass of pit coal per t coal equivalent (1 t coal equivalent equals 29.308 GJ) the energy content of pit coal can be calculated.  In this mining region a gross calorific value of 20.1 MJ/kg pit coal can be estimated. Based on the results for the different mining regions and weighted with the annual total production an average value of 19.1 MJ/kg can be calculated. This figure represents the gross calorific value for the exchange "coal, hard, unspecified in ground". 

To calculate the CED a correction factor has to be used in order to consider differences between calorific values for different hard coals. This factor (i.e. relative resource extraction) corresponds to the gross calorific value of respective mining region divided by the average gross calorific value worldwide. 

In this region 1,381 kg pit coal/ kg useable output are mined. 


Further references:

Frischknecht R., Jungbluth N., Althaus H.-J., Doka G., Dones R., Hischier R., Hellweg S., Humbert S., Margni M., Nemecek T. and Spielmann M. (2004c) Implementation of Life Cycle Impact Assessment Methods. Final report ecoinvent 2000 No. 3. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, retrieved from: www.ecoinvent.ch <http://www.ecoinvent.ch>.

Literature data : The above data is taken from Environment impact statement of  Carmichael Coal Mine project.50 % of the total land is assumed to be used for extraction and other 50% to be used as dump site. The environemental statement canbe downloaded from the below link https://www.statedevelopment.qld.gov.au/assessments-and-approvals/carmichael-coal-environmental-impact-statement.html The total mine area given is 44700 hectares with an annual prodction capacity of 60 MTPA with a mine life of 90 years.

Literature Data: The data for blasting/explosives used in coal mines is taken from environemental impact statement from Carmichael Coal Mine project.The data can be downloaded from the below links. Coal is embeded in roacks hence explosives are required to break the rocks and extract coal.  https://www.statedevelopment.qld.gov.au/assessments-and-approvals/carmichael-coal-environmental-impact-statement.html.

exchanges.description: This data point has been kept from the dataset "hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, AU 1990-2002", accessed 28th November 2017. The data point has been reviewed and deemed as still appropriate. Estimation.

This data point has been kept from the dataset "hard coal mine operation and hard coal preparation, AU 1990-2002", accessed 28th November 2017. The data point has been reviewed and deemed as still appropriate.                                                                                   Estimation. According to Astakhov and DOE mine water amounts to 0.5 m3/t with an average value of 1.3 m3/t for underground mines and 0.2 m3/t for opencast mines. Regarding opencast mines lower water amounts are expected. Due to lower depths and smaller seams also low salt contens are expected. Based on these facts it is assumed that 200 l/t water are pumped with a salt content of 0.5 g/l (i.e. 0.1 kg/t useable output). Respective emissions are calculated based on the share of coal mining in opencast and underground mines. 

Further references:

U.S. Departement of Energy (DOE) (1983) Energy Technonolgy Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. Washington, D.C.
